title: Recreate Redis Counters using Snowplow events - Phase 2: Wave 5d - FE EVENTS
description:
## Summary

In https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/7493, we instrumented the first set of Redis Counters using Snowplow events in SaaS. This is the 5th wave of counters to be instrumented using Snowplow Events. Splitting this counter, [redis_hll_counters.analytics.analytics_total_unique_counts_monthly](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/config/metrics/counts_28d/20210216175016_analytics_total_unique_counts_monthly.yml), into its own issue per [this comment](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/362281#note_1037697785) since the counter is made up of many sub-metrics.

In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/369846, the backend events needed for [redis_hll_counters.analytics.analytics_total_unique_counts_monthly](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/config/metrics/counts_28d/20210216175016_analytics_total_unique_counts_monthly.yml) were instrumented. This issue the FRONTEND events which is needed to ship this counter.
    
1. [ ] [redis_hll_counters.analytics.analytics_total_unique_counts_monthly](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/config/metrics/counts_28d/20210216175016_analytics_total_unique_counts_monthly.yml)


Submetrics that need to be migrated:
1. [x] i_analytics_dev_ops_adoption **FRONTEND**
1. [x] i_analytics_dev_ops_score **FRONTEND**
1. [x] p_analytics_ci_cd_pipelines **FRONTEND**
1. [x] p_analytics_ci_cd_deployment_frequency **FRONTEND**
1. [x] p_analytics_ci_cd_lead_time **FRONTEND**

                                           
## Feature Flag

These events should be instrumented behind a feature flag (separate from the FF used for the first wave of metrics) in case we need to quickly turn off collection.

## Next Step

Post delivery, the data team will need to aggregate the snowplow events into counters for use in Sisense and Gainsight. Data team issue for this wave: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-data/analytics/-/issues/13211

epic.title: Send RedisHLL metrics via Snowplow for SaaS namespaces - Phase 2

title: [Feature flag] Enable limited execution time cron worker for user destroy
description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Feature flag] Enable description of feature -->

## Summary

This issue is to rollout [the feature](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/366655) on production,
that is currently behind the `user_destroy_with_limited_execution_time_worker` feature flag.

<!-- Short description of what the feature is about and link to relevant other issues. -->

## Owners

- Team: ~"group::authentication and authorization" 
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_manage_access`
- Best individual to reach out to: `@ifarkas`
- PM: `@hsutor`

## Stakeholders

<!--
Are there any other stages or teams involved that need to be kept in the loop?

- Name of a PM
- The Support Team
- The Delivery Team
-->

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

<!-- Describe the expected outcome when rolling out this feature -->

No user faceing change. User deletion and migrating associated records to ghost user should be handled by `Users::MigrateRecordsToGhostUserInBatchesWorker`.

### When is the feature viable?

<!-- What are the settings we need to configure in order to have this feature viable? -->

<!-- 
Example below:
 
1. Enable service ping collection
   `ApplicationSetting.first.update(usage_ping_enabled: true)`
-->

After the merge of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/97165.

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

<!-- Should the feature flag be turned off? Any MRs that need to be rolled back? Communication that needs to happen? What are some things you can think of that could go wrong - data loss or broken pages? -->

User deletion blocked.

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

<!-- Which dashboards from https://dashboards.gitlab.net are most relevant? -->
_Consider mentioning checks for 5xx errors or other anomalies like an increase in redirects 
(302 HTTP response status)_

- Checking `Users::MigrateRecordsToGhostUserInBatchesWorker` jobs in Kibana
- checking `Users::GhostUserMigration` records in the DB: these should be short-lived records tracking the user migration / deletion process

### What can we check for monitoring production after rollouts?

_Consider adding links to check for Sentry errors, Production logs for 5xx, 302s, etc._

## Rollout Steps

### Rollout on non-production environments

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- [x] Enable the feature globally on non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true --dev --staging --staging-ref`
- [x] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.
      The best environment to validate the feature in is [staging-canary](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/#staging-canary)
      as this is the first environment deployed to. Note you will need to make sure you are configured to use canary as outlined [here](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/canary-stage/)
      when accessing the staging environment in order to make sure you are testing appropriately.

### Specific rollout on production

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to both production and canary.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- If you're using [project-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab,gitlab-org/gitlab-foss,gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com <feature-flag-name> true`
- If you're using [group-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --group=gitlab-org,gitlab-com <feature-flag-name> true`
- If you're using [user-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --user=<your-username> <feature-flag-name> true`
- [ ] Verify that the feature works on the specific entries. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Preparation before global rollout

- [x] Check if the feature flag change needs to be accompanied with a
  [change management issue](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/change-management/#feature-flags-and-the-change-management-process).
  Cross link the issue here if it does.
- [x] Ensure that you or a representative in development can be available for at least 2 hours after feature flag updates in production.
  If a different developer will be covering, or an exception is needed, please inform the oncall SRE by using the `@sre-oncall` Slack alias.
- [x] Ensure that documentation has been updated ([More info](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature_flags.html#features-that-became-enabled-by-default)).
- [x] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com. 
- [x] Ensure that any breaking changes have been announced following the [release post process](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/blog/release-posts/#deprecations-removals-and-breaking-changes) to ensure GitLab customers are aware.
- [x] Notify `#support_gitlab-com` and your team channel ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#communicate-the-change)).

### Global rollout on production

For visibility, all `/chatops` commands that target production should be executed in the `#production` slack channel and cross-posted (with the command results) to the responsible team's slack channel (`#g_TEAM_NAME`).

- [ ] [Incrementally roll out](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#process) the feature.
  - If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform **actor-based** rollout.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage> --actors`
  - If the feature flag in code does **NOT** have [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform time-based rollout (**random** rollout).
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage> --random`
  - Enable the feature globally on production environment.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true`
- [ ] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) that the feature has been globally enabled.
- [x] Wait for [at least one day for the verification term](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release).

### (Optional) Release the feature with the feature flag

If you're still unsure whether the feature is [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release)
but want to release it in the current milestone, you can change the default state of the feature flag to be enabled.
To do so, follow these steps:

- [ ] Create a merge request with the following changes. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [ ] Set the `default_enabled` attribute in [the feature flag definition](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-flag-definition-and-validation) to `true`.
    - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the default-enabling MR has been included in the release package.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the monthly release was tagged](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run release check <merge-request-url> <milestone>`
- [ ] Consider cleaning up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel. Otherwise these settings may override the default enabled.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --dev --staging --staging-ref --production`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [ ] Set the next milestone to this rollout issue for scheduling [the flag removal](#release-the-feature).
- [ ] (Optional) You can [create a separate issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) for scheduling the steps below to [Release the feature](#release-the-feature).
    - [ ] Set the title to "[Feature flag] Cleanup `<feature-flag-name>`".
    - [ ] Execute the `/copy_metadata <this-rollout-issue-link>` quick action to copy the labels from this rollout issue.
    - [ ] Link this rollout issue as a related issue.
    - [ ] Close this rollout issue.

**WARNING:** This approach has the downside that it makes it difficult for us to
[clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) the flag.
For example, on-premise users could disable the feature on their GitLab instance. But when you
remove the flag at some point, they suddenly see the feature as enabled and they can't roll it back
to the previous behavior. To avoid this potential breaking change, use this approach only for urgent
matters.

### Release the feature

After the feature has been [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release),
the [clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up)
should be done as soon as possible to permanently enable the feature and reduce complexity in the
codebase.

You can either [create a follow-up issue for Feature Flag Cleanup](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) or use the checklist below in this same issue.

<!-- The checklist here is to help stakeholders keep track of the feature flag status -->
- [x] Create a merge request to remove `<feature-flag-name>` feature flag. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [x] Remove all references to the feature flag from the codebase.
    - [x] Remove the YAML definitions for the feature from the repository.
    - [x] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [x] Ensure that the cleanup MR has been included in the release package.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the monthly release was tagged](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run release check <merge-request-url> <milestone>`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [x] If not already done, clean up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel:
    - [x] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --dev --staging --staging-ref --production`
- [x] Close this rollout issue.

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> false
```

title: Update translations levels (October 2022)
description:
## Introduction

With the implementation of the feature to show the [translation coverage](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/328430) in the language selection dropdown, the translation levels need to be updated on a monthly cadence.

## Proposal

Once the monthly merge of the new translations is complete, update the translation levels [data](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/i18n.rb#L43) from Crowdin.

## Documentation

* https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/i18n/merging_translations.html#manually-update-the-translation-levels

#### ToDo

* [x] After cloning: update Title, set Milestone, Due date (15th), Related to previous month's issue.
* [x] After the 1st of the month: assign to yourself, set ~2526320
* [x] Complete the [regular monthly merge](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3571) of translations from Crowdin.
* [x] Get the translation levels (% approved words) from [Crowdin](https://crowdin.com/project/gitlab-ee).
* [x] Create an MR to update the translation levels [data](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/i18n.rb#L43).
* [x] Associate that MR to this issue.
* [x] Complete the MR.
* [x] When done, clone [this template issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/349815) for the next milestone.

title: Merge i18n translations (October 2022)
description:
Merge the latest i18n translations from Crowdin on a monthly cadence.

Documentation available here: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/i18n/merging_translations.html

#### ToDo

* [x] Find the [MR](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests?scope=all&utf8=%E2%9C%93&state=opened&author_username=gitlab-crowdin-bot) created by @gitlab-crowdin-bot and associate it with this issue
* [x] Complete the MR
* [x] Update the translation levels [data](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/i18n.rb#L43) with the latest numbers. (Find the issue [here](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3571))
* [x] When done, clone [this template issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/339980) for the next milestone.

title: Validate/Lint that the trigger:project: must not be an array
description:
We don't document that `trigger:project` can be an array but we in-consistently enforce that it can only be a string. This leads to a bug when the user specifies an array. See: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/ops-sub-department/section-ops-request-for-help/-/issues/25

Below are two equivalent syntaxes but both should be invalid:

1. invalid yaml according to the linter:

```yaml
do:
  trigger: [allison.browne/multiproject2]
```

2. valid yaml according to the linter (but shouldn't be):

```yaml
do:
  trigger: 
    project: [allison.browne/multiproject2]
```

## Implementation

| ~backend | MR |
| ------ | ------ |
| Add CI string validation to trigger:project | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/107275 |

title: Create a shared security training promo component
description:
Let's abstract the current `security_training_promo.vue` component into a shared component so it can be used in both the MR widget and on the project vulnerability page.

| Vulnerability Page (exist) | MR widget (new) |
| ------ | ------ |
| ![image](/uploads/0352da3696feb6839a5022c2a6cae431/image.png) | ![image](/uploads/b973d3eaed870fb1f9488620755d1eef/image.png) |

## Implementaion Plan

Each step will be implemented iteratively in individual MRs:

1. Rename and move the current vulnerability `security_training_promo.vue`.

```diff
- ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/components/shared/security_training_promo.vue
+ ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/components/project/security_training_promo_banner.vue
```

_thought_: since this component is only used on the project page, I don't think it needs to live in the `shared` folder.

---

2. Create a shared `security_training_promo.vue` component > https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/373272

```diff
+ ee/app/assets/javascripts/vue_shared/security_reports/components/security_training_promo.vue
```

- 2a. _Nice to have:_ Create story book entry for the new `security_training_promo.vue` component > https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/373273

---

3. Update the `security_training_promo_banner.vue` to use the shared `security_training_promo.vue` component. (And update related specs) > https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/373274

```bash
# security_training_promo_banner.vue
# High level pseudo code
<security-training-promo>
  <gl-banner>vulnerability page training promo banner UI</gl-banner>
</security-training-promo>
```

---

4. Use this new shared `security_training_promo.vue` component for the MR widget. _Note: I'll track this in a different issue > https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/346064_

```diff
+ ee/app/assets/javascripts/vue_merge_request_widget/extensions/security_reports/security_training_promo_mr_widget.vue
```

```bash
# security_training_promo_mr_widget.vue
# High level pseudo code
<security-training-promo>
  <div>MR widget training promo UI<div>
</security-training-promo>
```

title: MR License Compliance Widget not showing on staging as old widget unavailable
description:
As per failure on Staging noted in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/372959

It was noticed that License Compliance widget was no longer appearing on Merge Requests.

The old vue has been removed, `refactor_mr_widgets_extensions` FF was turned off.

From @farias-gl Slack https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/CV2M96LJG/p1662635014427389

> Hey team, ran into a weird edge case with feature flags. I think license compliance is the first widget to have the old design removed in this MR. But this also means if we ever turn off `:refactor_mr_widgets_extensions` then we won't show any license compliance widgets,  since the old vue doesn't exist anymore


## Analysis

`:refactor_mr_widgets_extensions` flag was off in staging, but enabled in production and self-managed via the YML file.

I turned on the flag in staging so the new widget is visible in staging https://staging.gitlab.com/secure-team-test/security-reports/-/merge_requests/28

## Options

### Decouple flag

WIP MR https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/97536 to see if we can enable decouple the widget from the `:refactor_mr_widgets_extensions`

`:refactor_mr_widgets_extensions`

| `:refactor_mr_widgets_extensions` | header |
| ------ | ------ |
| On | ![Screen_Shot_2022-09-09_at_7.33.21_PM](/uploads/92955f171ebcc3d6be3c0911d93067de/Screen_Shot_2022-09-09_at_7.33.21_PM.png) |
| Off | ![Screen_Shot_2022-09-09_at_7.34.34_PM](/uploads/18050b1e2de4a94e3bcdc7ab27c3b305/Screen_Shot_2022-09-09_at_7.34.34_PM.png)|

title: Exec Dashboards: New page backend POC with "Metrics comparative table "
description:
Manage:Optimize

## Overview

This issue is for the ~backend work in the Exec Dashboards new page POC.

Splitting from https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/372502+ and from the full [Exec Dashboards spec](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/370887).

## Problem to solve

GitLab Analytics provide high value to executives. However, these reports are spread across multiple pages in GitLab and may require specific filters to be applied to be relevant. Executives' time is very valuable, and we want it to be intuitive for them to use GitLab to get insights that are relevant to their business.

![Screen_Shot_2022-09-15_at_2.51.09_PM](/uploads/f2507b489f6afaffca1ec3af6b7cb631/Screen_Shot_2022-09-15_at_2.51.09_PM.png)

## Proposed solution

Build proof of concept of on a new page with "Metrics comparative table ".

1. Create a new group-level page /analytics/exec_dashboards.
1. The new page will contain custom table view with multiple gitlab metrics.
1. The API queries will be against gitlab-org production database.
1. Each tile should have a drill-down link into other GL analytics reports.
1. The new page will be behind a feature flag.
1. Page name "Exec Dashboards POC".
1. View "Edit" mode don't need a detailed UI, it can can be customized via yaml or json.
1. Metrics filter options - per project and / or sub-groups.
1. For this POC the measurements dimensions will be time period.
1. Columns headers - Name | Period 1 | Period 2 | Change % | Description
1. Timespan for the POC - 90 days
1. Name - Metric name
1. Period 1 - period 1 value. For the POC = Last full calendar month.
1. Period 2 - period 2 value. For the POC = Previous full calendar month (-2).
1. Change % - % = (Current period Value  Previous period value) / Previous period value
1. Description - Open text
1. Each value need to be displayed with value_unit - (e.g. deployment frequency with "/day", Lead Time for Changes "days", Change Failure Rate "%")

### This specific issue requirements

* Create a new group-level page /analytics/exec_dashboards.
* Add a feature flag for the new page.

## Acceptance criteria

Compare DORA Deployment Frequency `value` and `change rate %` across 4 different projects.

## Out of scope:

1. Table sorting
1. Change badge with colors (Red/Green
1. Sparklines to show data trends.
1. Sub-views
1. Add Target / Goal value (configure manually by the user).
1. Specific date range

## Validation

* [Analytics Dashboard Investigation](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/manage/general-discussion/-/issues/17169).
* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/353651+

epic.title: Exec Dashboards: New page POC with "Metrics comparative table"

title: Exec Dashboards: New page frontend POC with "Metrics comparative table "
description:
## Overview 

This issue is for the ~frontend work in the Exec Dashboards new page POC. 

Splitting from https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/372502+ and from the full [Exec Dashboards spec](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/370887). 

## Problem to solve

GitLab Analytics provide high value to executives. However, these reports are spread across multiple pages in GitLab and may require specific filters to be applied to be relevant. 
Executives' time is very valuable, and they might not know how to use GitLab to get insights that are relevant to their business.


## Proposed solution

Build proof of concept of on a new page with "Metrics comparative table ". 

1. Create a new group-level page /analytics/dashboards.
1. The new page will contain custom table view with multiple gitlab metrics. 
1. The API queries will be against gitlab-org production database.
1. Each tile should have a drill-down link into other GL analytics reports.
1. The new page will be behind a feature flag.
1. Page name "Exec Dashboards POC".
1. For this POC the measurements dimensions will be time period.  
1. Columns headers - Name | Period 1 | Period 2 | Change % | Description
1. Timespan for the POC - 90 days
1. Name - Metric name 
1. Period 1 - period 1 value.  For the POC = Last full calendar month. 
1. Period 2 - period 2 value. For the POC = Previous full calendar month (-2).
1. Change % - % = (Current period Value  Previous period value) / Previous period value
1. Description - Open text
2. Each value need to be displayed with value_unit - (e.g. deployment frequency with "/day", Lead Time for Changes "days", Change Failure Rate "%")

## Acceptance criteria

Compare DORA Deployment Frequency `value` and `change rate %` across 4 different projects.

## Out of scope:

1.  View "Edit" mode don't need a detailed UI, it can can be customized via yaml or json. (Out of scope for this issue)
    1. Select which metrics to displayed in the table. 
    2. Metrics filter options - per project and / or sub-groups.Table sorting 
2. Change badge with colors (Red/Green
2. Sparklines to show data trends.
3. Sub-views
4. Add Target / Goal value (configure manually by the user).
5. Specific date range

## Validation 

* [Analytics Dashboard Investigation](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/manage/general-discussion/-/issues/17169).
* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/353651+

title: Improve UX of `Clear status after` field
description:
Follow-up from https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/96800#note_1090313115

The UX for the `Clear status after` field when setting your status is a little confusing. When you choose a value and then submit the form a message is added below the dropdown that says `Your status resets on 2022-09-08 00:41:43 UTC.` and the dropdown is changed back to `Never`. So then when the user comes back it isn't clear if your status will clear on the date or if it will never clear.

### Proposed solution

- User sees `Clear status after` dropdown with options as they are today
- User selects an option
- If the user returns via the update status option they see a date or time as the dropdown text
  - If the user chose a time (30 min, 3 hours, 8 hours) they see a time for example 3:30 pm EDT
  - If the user chose a date (1 day, ..., 30 days) they see a date for example Oct 2, 2022
  - This is just the display in the dropdown, the options would still be the same as in we **don't** need an option that displays Oct 2, 2022.
- We could get rid of the helper text `Your status resets on 2022-09-16 15:18:24 UTC.`

![image](/uploads/0fddc5f7cfeb772d3ac1f15f5a5b1ebf/image.png)

### Availability and Testing
- No new E2E tests or updates needed at this time. Please update unit and integration tests as necessary.
- Consider adding a feature spec to `spec/features/profiles/user_edit_profile_spec.rb` within the `user status` context that tests the following cases:
  - User chooses a time option, closes the modal, revisits the modal, and sees correct time populated in the dropdown
    - Keep in mind edge cases, such as a time option that overlaps to the next day
  - User chooses a date option, closes the modal, revisits the modal, and sees correct date populated in the dropdown

title: GitLab for Jira app: Fix content security policy problems
description:
This is a part of the epic to make the GitLab for Jira app available for self-managed (https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/5650)

GitLab SaaS will act as a proxy for a self-managed instance and therefore will have to call a few endpoints. To allow this, they need to be added to the content security policy. We already did this with `/-/jira_connect/oauth_application_id` [here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/58c73999b3214564c2755caeb111681d09b65d10/app/controllers/jira_connect/subscriptions_controller.rb#L70).

In addition to this, we need to allow

- `/-/jira_connect/*`
- `/api/*`

On the self-managed side, we need to add `/-/jira_connect/subscriptions` to allowed origins in application.rb

title: Finish review fails when "approve" box is checked on already-approved MR
description:
### Summary The "Submit review" button will fail to submit a MR review when you check the "approve MR" box for an MR that you already approved. ### Steps to reproduce 1. Create MR in a project that requires at least one approval 2. Add one or more comments to the review 3. Approve the MR 4. Click "Finish review" 5. Check the "Approve merge request" box ### Example Project https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/govern/demos/sandbox/test-approval-bug/-/merge_requests/2 ### What is the current *bug* behavior? Error appears: "An error occurred while approving, please try again." ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? Review is submitted. No errors. MR stays approved. ### Relevant logs and/or screenshots ![image](/uploads/64c74dbb77515273a8d03b3e17ddb729/image.png) Note MR is already approved, which is probably why we get the error: ![image](/uploads/15306d34baac68d8cc6b6e3948c0dde7/image.png) ### Output of checks This bug happens on GitLab.com #### Results of GitLab environment info
Expand for output related to GitLab environment info 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:env:info`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:env:info RAILS_ENV=production`)
#### Results of GitLab application Check
Expand for output related to the GitLab application check 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:check SANITIZE=true`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:check RAILS_ENV=production SANITIZE=true`)

(we will only investigate if the tests are passing)
### Possible fixes The request `POST https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/govern/demos/sandbox/test-approval-bug/-/merge_requests/2/drafts/publish` fails with: ``` 500 Internal Server Error {"message":"An error occurred while approving, please try again."} ``` This is arguably a ~backend bug. The HTTP status should be `200` with a message of "already approved".

description:

If we receive an [installed webhook](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/connect-app-descriptor/#lifecycle-http-request-payload) from Jira for a `JiraConnectInstallation` that already exists and has an `instance_url`, we have to forward the webhook to the self-managed instance. This can re-use the solution outlined in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/372967

title: GitLab for Jira app: Send installed event for Jira app installed updated for self-managed
description:
This is a part of the epic to make the GitLab for Jira app available for self-managed (https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/5650)

The summary of the whole feature is that GitLab.com will act as a proxy for the self-managed instance. This means we will need a `JiraConnectInstallation` record on .com and self-managed.

The installation record gets created with a [webhook](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/connect-app-descriptor/#lifecycle-http-request-payload) that we usually receive from Jira. With the proxy in place, the hook has to come from GitLab.

The hook contains:

- A shared secret that needs to be stored and will be used to authorize future requests.
- A JWT token

### Problem with [asymmetric JWTs](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/understanding-jwt-for-connect-apps/#verifying-a-asymmetric-jwt-token-for-install-callbacks):

A public key is needed to decode the JWT in the installed hook. The key can be fetched from `connect-install-keys.atlassian.com/{{KEY_ID}}` and `KEY_ID` is included in the JWT's `kid` header.

We don't store the JWT token that was included in the installed hook to GitLab.com. So we have to construct a new token, but this won't match a public key at Atlassian.

**Solution:**

We can offer an endpoint to fetch public keys from on GitLab.com

The security measure in asymmetric JWT is that the domain to fetch the public key is fixed. It points to `connect-install-keys.atlassian.com`. We can make this an application setting, so users can point it to `gitlab.com/-/jira_connect/public_keys` instead. This would require:

* An application setting to configure the CDN URL
* A DB table or Redis cache to store public keys
* A route to return public keys

epic.title: Self-managed support extended to GitLab for Jira app

title: Duplicate attacks are not sent
description:
### Problem

Even if duplicate HTTP messages are filtered out when loading them from the database, as injections alter the attack request it is possible to have duplicates after injections are applied.

Duplicate attack requests add to the scan time with no added value to the scan result.

### Proposal

Duplicate attack requests should be removed.

### Example 

Two requests loaded from the database may have the following URL:

- `https://site.com/people`
- `https://site.com/people?sort=name`

When the request path injection location finds places to inject attacks, it returns the following (it removes query parameters):

1. `https://site.com/<location>`
1. `https://site.com/<location>`

When an injection is applied, e.g. `../etc/password`, the result is duplicate attack requests.

1. `https://site.com/../etc/password`
1. `https://site.com/../etc/password`

### Implementation plan

- [x] The attack request factory can create an attack request from the crawledHTTPRequest, location and injection. It should return whether or not the attack request is a duplicate as well as the new attack request `Build(*HTTPRequest, InjectionLocation, Injection) (AttackRequest, bool)`
- [x] The attack request factory should maintain an internal cache to see if the attack request has been seen before https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/875
- [x] Attack request can hash its fields (apart from ID). The hash can be used to determine uniqueness https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/875
- [x] Every time an attack request is created, update the cache https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/875
- [x] The cache should be maintained per check ID. That is, `map[string]map[string]struct{}`. This means duplicates are applied per check (different checks will apply different injections). i.e. `map[check.id][active request hash] = struct{}{}` https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/875
- [x] The cache should be accessed using a mutex, or a concurrent map should be used for all cache maps https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/875
- [x] If the factory determines that the attack request has been seen before, then return `nil, true` https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/875
- [x] Timing attack and match response attack should check to see if the attack request is a duplicate by reading the boolean value returned https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/875
- [x] The log in timing attack and match response attack should occur after the attack request is built. That way, nothing is logged if it is a duplicate. https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/875
- [x] Timing attacks should not send duplicate attack requests in the first loop https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/888#note_1135235031
- [x] Exclude headers and authorization cookies from headers when Hashing attack request https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/888#note_1135371924

title: Incorrect gitlab-ci.yml syntax in API Security documentation
description:
### Problem

The documentation for API Security includes numerous examples of GitLab CI/CD YAML. Some of the examples use invalid/incorrect syntax that will cause errors if a user attempts to use them as-is.

Example of incorrect syntax:

```yaml
variables:
  DAST_API_EXCLUDE_PATHS=/auth
```

What is should look like:

```yaml
variables:
  DAST_API_EXCLUDE_PATHS: /auth
```

or

```yaml
variables:
  - DAST_API_EXCLUDE_PATHS=/auth
```

### Proposal

Find all GitLab CI/CD YAML examples that use an `=` sign in variables and convert it to `: `, making sure that the items are not a list (prefixed with ` -`.

title: Use IID + full path for Tasks
description:
## Problem

> the reason for different behaviour is the same that we had for assignees and labels - the root path for the work item is not equal the path in the URL. I fixed this behaviour for assignees and labels in a hacky way - by fetching project path within the work item itself. Should we go the same path for description too or should we prioritize changing the URL to project-relative one? [Slack thread](https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/C02403NRD40/p1662125833613599?thread_ts=1662123437.916179&cid=C02403NRD40)

Additional context -- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-design/-/issues/1514#note_1052454929

## Proposal

Use the project's `IID` and full path for tasks instead of the `ID`.

title: Active checks run against all crawled HTTP messages
description:
### Problem

Active checks search for injection locations on HTTP requests that were discovered as part of the crawl phase. Currently, only a subset of these HTTP requests are searched, resulting in a significant amount of true-positives to be missed in the scan.

### Proposal

- Record the order Navigations/Navigation Results are crawled so that active scans are more deterministic
- Navigation Result HTTP messages should be retrieved based on the order they were crawled
- Loading HTTP messages should be chunked, so that only 10 messages are loaded at a time. This ensures that memory usage is not excessive
- The number of messages loaded at a time should be configurable by the user
- HTTP messages should be filtered so that duplicates (by request method, URL) are not returned
- HTTP message duplication removal should happen only once (cache)
- Investigate the performance implicates of whatever solution is implemented


### Implementation plan

- [x] Store a new field `CreatedAtIndex` on `NavigationResult`
- [x] The `NavigationResultRecorder` should store an integer representing the order a NavigationResult is processed
  - Each time a new navigation is created, increment the order
  - Order should be accessed using a mutex
- [x] Loading a navigation result from the database should return the order crawled
- [x] The navigation result store should be able to return a HTTPMessageCursor (or iterator)
  - The cursor contains a list of chunked HTTP Message IDs (chunked into size 10)
  - The database transaction should be closed when the cursor is returned (i.e. don't have long lived transactions)
  - Use a channel as a generator so that the following API works: `for httpMessage := range httpMessagesCursor.Read() {`
    - `Read` hides the chunking, and retrieving from the navigation result store
    - This should not require creating many goroutines
    - Example: http://www.golangpatterns.info/concurrency/generators
- [x] Remove duplicates as they are read by the cursor
- [x] Cache duplicates so that getting another cursor only loads the required non-duplicate HTTP messages
- [ ] ~~The chunk size is configurable by the user `ACTIVE_SCAN_LOAD_MESSAGE_CHUNK_SIZE=3`~~ we can do this later if required.
- [x] Remove unused functions
  - [x] `DatabaseHTTPMessageStore.FindAll`, `HTTPMessageQuery`, `httpMessageQueryBuilder`
- [x] Only return messages that are not duplicates
- [x] Only return messages that are in scope
- [x] Remove `HTTPMessageStore.GetScopeService`, rename `DatabaseHTTPMessageStore.ScopeService` to be private, remove `httpMessageStore.ScopeService =` in test.
- [x] Create a query for iterating HTTP messages from a navigation result

title: Create API to list entities that will be deleted when deleting a user
description:
Manage:Workspace

### Problem to solve

From this conversation: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/364090#note_1086086211

This is helpful for instance administrators to get an understanding of that user's reach and contributions in an instance before deleting that user. It gives them a sense of the impact of deleting that specific account.

An instance admin can run this endpoint to gather metrics around the contributions of each user in the instance to understand the impact of deleting that person.

### Proposal
Introduce new API endpoint like `GET /users/:id/entity_counts` (or, a better name) that exposes these counts using a new serializer.

API will be used in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/364090 to display entities that will be deleted when deleting a user.

### Availability and Testing
- No new E2E tests or updates needed at this time. 
- Recommend adding a new request spec in addition to other unit and integration test updates.
- Consider testing the performance of this endpoint on a user with a very large amount of contributions across many groups and projects, similar to a real world scenario on GitLab.com.

title: Do not show "cleanup policies are disabled at admin level" notification while page is loading
description:
The following discussion from !97085 should be addressed: [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/97085#note_1090037289):  (+1 comment)

## Problem
When loading or re-loading the container registry cleanup policy form (Settings > Packages & Registries > Clean up image tags), a notification is shown that the Container Registry cleanup policies are disabled at the admin level. If they are **not** disabled, that notification goes away and is replaced by the cleanup form.

5 second Loom recording: https://www.loom.com/share/815a4fa5a09d48199fac7b67a14b33e3

Note: depending on when this issue is picked up, the container registry cleanup form may be on the main settings page or on its own page.

| Main settings page | Container Registry cleanup on new page |
| ------ | ------ |
|![Screen_Shot_2022-09-06_at_15.29.56](/uploads/c70e852fd4fa3d39d0cabdd6c24afe87/Screen_Shot_2022-09-06_at_15.29.56.png) |![Screen_Shot_2022-09-06_at_15.29.48](/uploads/a7a3f78294e9e664ae3db0c70b8b435a/Screen_Shot_2022-09-06_at_15.29.48.png) |

## Solution
* When the page is loading, do not show the notification that the cleanup policies are disabled on the admin level
* If the cleanup policies **are** disabled on an admin level, show this notification
* If the cleanup policies **are not** disabled on an admin level, never show this notification

## Implementation plan

- Add extra check in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/packages_and_registries/settings/project/components/cleanup_image_tags.vue before showing `else` block.

title: Fetch one job from GraphQL
[Feature flag] Rollout of ci_project_pipeline_config_refactoring
description:
## Summary

This issue is to rollout the refactoring !97240 on production,
that is currently behind the `ci_project_pipeline_config_refactoring` feature flag.

## Owners

- Team: ~"group::pipeline authoring" 
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_pipeline-authoring`
- Best individual to reach out to: @furkanayhan 

## Stakeholders

~"group::pipeline execution" `@fabiopitino` `@allison.browne`

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

We expect nothing changes because it is just a refactoring change.

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

We can turn off the FF.

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

- Pipeline creation errors: https://sentry.gitlab.net/gitlab/gitlabcom/?query=CreatePipelineWorker
- We should not see a decrease of 201 response code of `Projects::PipelinesController#create` endpoint: https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/goto/7d638af810e4b002de03d9df7132175c

## Rollout Steps

### Rollout on non-production environments

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to non-production environments.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- [ ] Enable the feature globally on non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set ci_project_pipeline_config_refactoring true --dev --staging --staging-ref`
- [ ] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.
      The best environment to validate the feature in is [staging-canary](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/#staging-canary)
      as this is the first environment deployed to. Note you will need to make sure you are configured to use canary as outlined [here](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/canary-stage/)
      when accessing the staging environment in order to make sure you are testing appropriately.

### Specific rollout on production

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to both production and canary.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- If you're using [project-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab,gitlab-org/gitlab-foss,gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com ci_project_pipeline_config_refactoring true`
- If you're using [group-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --group=gitlab-org,gitlab-com ci_project_pipeline_config_refactoring true`
- If you're using [user-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --user=<your-username> ci_project_pipeline_config_refactoring true`
- [ ] Verify that the feature works on the specific entries. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Preparation before global rollout

- [ ] Check if the feature flag change needs to be accompanied with a
  [change management issue](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/change-management/#feature-flags-and-the-change-management-process).
  Cross link the issue here if it does.
- [ ] Ensure that you or a representative in development can be available for at least 2 hours after feature flag updates in production.
  If a different developer will be covering, or an exception is needed, please inform the oncall SRE by using the `@sre-oncall` Slack alias.
- [ ] Ensure that documentation has been updated ([More info](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature_flags.html#features-that-became-enabled-by-default)).
- [ ] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com. 
- [ ] Ensure that any breaking changes have been announced following the [release post process](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/blog/release-posts/#deprecations-removals-and-breaking-changes) to ensure GitLab customers are aware.
- [ ] Notify `#support_gitlab-com` and your team channel ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#communicate-the-change)).

### Global rollout on production

For visibility, all `/chatops` commands that target production should be executed in the `#production` slack channel and cross-posted (with the command results) to the responsible team's slack channel (`#g_TEAM_NAME`).

- [ ] [Incrementally roll out](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#process) the feature.
  - If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform **actor-based** rollout.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set ci_project_pipeline_config_refactoring <rollout-percentage> --actors`
  - If the feature flag in code does **NOT** have [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform time-based rollout (**random** rollout).
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set ci_project_pipeline_config_refactoring <rollout-percentage> --random`
  - Enable the feature globally on production environment.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set ci_project_pipeline_config_refactoring true`
- [ ] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) that the feature has been globally enabled.
- [ ] Wait for [at least one day for the verification term](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release).

### (Optional) Release the feature with the feature flag

If you're still unsure whether the feature is [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release)
but want to release it in the current milestone, you can change the default state of the feature flag to be enabled.
To do so, follow these steps:

- [ ] Create a merge request with the following changes. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [ ] Set the `default_enabled` attribute in [the feature flag definition](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-flag-definition-and-validation) to `true`.
    - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the default-enabling MR has been included in the release package.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the monthly release was tagged](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run release check <merge-request-url> <milestone>`
- [ ] Consider cleaning up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel. Otherwise these settings may override the default enabled.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete ci_project_pipeline_config_refactoring --dev --staging --staging-ref --production`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [ ] Set the next milestone to this rollout issue for scheduling [the flag removal](#release-the-feature).
- [ ] (Optional) You can [create a separate issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) for scheduling the steps below to [Release the feature](#release-the-feature).
    - [ ] Set the title to "[Feature flag] Cleanup `ci_project_pipeline_config_refactoring`".
    - [ ] Execute the `/copy_metadata <this-rollout-issue-link>` quick action to copy the labels from this rollout issue.
    - [ ] Link this rollout issue as a related issue.
    - [ ] Close this rollout issue.

**WARNING:** This approach has the downside that it makes it difficult for us to
[clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) the flag.
For example, on-premise users could disable the feature on their GitLab instance. But when you
remove the flag at some point, they suddenly see the feature as enabled and they can't roll it back
to the previous behavior. To avoid this potential breaking change, use this approach only for urgent
matters.

### Release the feature

After the feature has been [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release),
the [clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up)
should be done as soon as possible to permanently enable the feature and reduce complexity in the
codebase.

You can either [create a follow-up issue for Feature Flag Cleanup](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) or use the checklist below in this same issue.

<!-- The checklist here is to help stakeholders keep track of the feature flag status -->
- [ ] Create a merge request to remove `ci_project_pipeline_config_refactoring` feature flag. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [ ] Remove all references to the feature flag from the codebase.
    - [ ] Remove the YAML definitions for the feature from the repository.
    - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the cleanup MR has been included in the release package.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the monthly release was tagged](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run release check <merge-request-url> <milestone>`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [ ] If not already done, clean up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete ci_project_pipeline_config_refactoring --dev --staging --staging-ref --production`
- [ ] Close this rollout issue.

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set ci_project_pipeline_config_refactoring false
```

title: Add branch rules details to the list of branch rules
description:
### Description

In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/362217 we've added the ability to list branch rules under `Repository > Settings`. 

Currently, we only expose the `name` in the GraphQL endpoint, but the design requires us to also list branch rule details related to each branch rule.

### Scope

Looking at [`branch_rule_type.rb`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/graphql/types/projects/branch_rule_type.rb) right now we only expose `name`. We should also expose the branch rule details and render in on the frontend accordingly.

This issue addresses the sections marked in red:

![image](/uploads/5c11601e869d17a1ca5a7f3022427d65/image.png)

**Example (GraphQL reponse):**

```javascript
[{
  name: 'test-*', // branch or wildcard name
  isDefault: true, // whether on not it is the default branch
  isProtected: true, // whether a protection has been added to the branch
  details: ['2 matching branches', 'Requires CODEOWNERS approval', '2 status checks'], // details/summary of the protections
}]
```

### Testing

Regression testing with full run `package-and-test` recommended

title: User can configure maximum active scan time
description:
### Problem

Active scans can take a long time, and the user cannot determine when to stop search for vulnerability findings. 

### Proposal


- The user can configure a timeout for how long an active scan takes to run using the setting `ActiveScanTimeout = "1h20m"`
- The timer should start counting from when the active scan starts
- The active scan should stop immediately once the timeout is reached
- A gl-dast-report.json file should be generated and the scan completed successfully whether the active scan times out or not
- The timeout should have no effect if the scan is not an active scan
- Add a log message if the active scan times out

### Implementation plan

- [X] User can configure the `Config.Timeouts.activeScanTimeout` using the TOML configuration `ActiveScanTimeout = "1h20m"` https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/896
- [x] `ActiveCheckService.RunActiveChecks` should create a context `context.WithTimeout(..)`. https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/899
- [x] The context should be passed through to all functions that take a substantial amount of time
- [x] The function should check if the context is done, if it is, return (can use `ctx.Err()`) https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/899
- [x] Places to use the context:
  - [x] **required** [The next check in `ActiveChecksService.RunActiveChecks` should not run if the context is cancelled](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/899)
  - [x] **required** [The database query `NavigationResult.IterateHTTPMessages` could return early if the context is cancelled](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/915)
  - [ ] **nice-to-have** The injectors `InjectionLocationDetector.Search` could return early if the context is cancelled
  - [x] **required** [`ActiveCheck.RunAttacks` should pass the context to `command.RelatedTasks` to stop any new attacks executing](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/905)
  - [x] **required** [`WebServerGateway.Send` should be passed the context from each attack type. This allows `http.Client` to cancel the reques.](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/908/diffs)
- [X] Set a default active scan timeout of 3 hours https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/896
- [X] Log a message on INFO if the active scan times out https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/898
- [x] **required** [Review `dast` engineering meeting issue and add `e2e` test](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/915)

title: Vulnerability training message is contradictory
description:
### Problem

On some vulnerabilities when training is not available, a user gets a message that immediately contradicts itself. See the following screenshot. 

![Stripe_detected__please_remove_and_revoke_it_if_this_is_a_leak____GitLab_org___security-products___analyzers___browserker___GitLab](/uploads/0cd107143670a0e14f8276405a54d4bb/Stripe_detected__please_remove_and_revoke_it_if_this_is_a_leak____GitLab_org___security-products___analyzers___browserker___GitLab.png)

### Solution

Remove the "Learn more about this vulnerability and the best way to solve it" text from the UI. All other text and behaviors are unchanged.

### Verification Steps

1. Access a project with vulnerabilities
2. From the Vulnerability Report, click into a vulnerability to access the the vulnerability details page (eg. https://gitlab.com/gitlab-examples/security/security-reports/-/security/vulnerabilities/2971993)
3. Confirm the "Learn more about this vulnerability and the best way to solve it" text is no longer present beneath the training header.

title: Create a new protected branches shared view
description:
### Problem description

As described in the parent epic https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/8679 Users want to be able to have standardized workflows across teams and projects and leverage protected branches as a way to do this.

### Implementation plan

* Copy the [existing EE project settings](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/ee/app/views/projects/protected_branches/ee/_index.html.haml#L8) to a new section for EE groups
* Move the [shared protected_branches](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/views/projects/protected_branches/shared) files to a new shared location for projects and groups
* Update the [shared edit form](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/views/projects/protected_branches/shared/_protected_branch.html.haml#L2) and other partials to accept variables so that it can also be used for groups.
  * Make sure the data URL is also using the groups protected branch path too.
  * It might make sense to break this form into group/project files rather than having if checks.
* Replace text `Branch was deleted` with `Branch does not exist` in [protected branch partial ](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/views/projects/protected_branches/shared/_protected_branch.html.haml#L23).
* Update specs.

Note

Can be developed in parallel with the ~backend

title: Change the sort order of completed iterations
description:
## Problem

Currently, when you go to the closed iterations (..-/iterations) it auto-sorts the OLDEST ones at the top, which is basically the opposite if what you usually want. There is no search or filter either, so this is particularly annoying as time goes by and the number of iterations increases

## Proposal

Sort the list of closed iterations to show the most recently completed iterations first.

title: Active check attacks can configure the attack HTTP request timeouts
description:
### Problem

Certain timing attacks will require long response times, and will therefore require the ability to increase the attack HTTP request timeout.

### Proposal

- Timing attacks can define a HTTP request timeout in the YAML definition
- The timeout value is parsed, and made available to the attack
- When the timing attack sends an attack HTTP request, the timeout should be used
  - The attack timeout should take precedence over the default attack timeout
  - The attack timeout should take precedence over any user-specified timeout (see [user sets default attack timeout](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/372692])
- Suggested YAML for setting the timeout:
  ```yaml
  timing_attack:
    attack_request_timeout: "15s"
  ```

### Implementation plan

- [ ] Parser can parse the timing attack `attack_request_timeout` value
- [ ] TimingAttack is injected with the appropriate timeout
  - Alternatively, the TimingAttack is injected with an implementation of `WebServerGateway` that has the timeout applied
- [ ] When the timing attack sends an attack request, the timeout is included in the call
- [ ] The `HTTPClientWebServerGateway` uses the timeout in the `http.Client`

title: Progressively load CI/CD variable for 100+
description: There was an issue with the new graphQL variables queries because we limit the number of fetched variables to 100. We need to use pagination and fetch the first 100, then load the next batch either as we scroll or on clicking a button (load more)

title: User can configure the default attack HTTP request timeout
description:
### Problem

Customers with a slower than normal website may require increasing the timeout on attack HTTP requests.

### Proposal

Users can configure the default attack HTTP request timeout.

### Implementation plan

- [x] User can configure the `Config.Timeouts.attackRequestTimeout` using the TOML configuration `AttackRequestTimeout = "30s"`
- [x] The `HTTPClientWebServerGateway` accepts the timeout as a constructor functional option
- [x] The timeout is used in the `http.Client` `Timeout`
- [x] If not set by the user, the default timeout is set to `30 seconds`

title: Injection location detectors return an error when dealing with non-standard HTTP requests
description:
### Problem

Active check injection location detectors are silently handling errors. This can lead to scans silently succeeding when in fact they actually failed. 

### Proposal

Injection location detectors should return an error, both when searching and modifying requests. Errors should be logged, and the scan should continue.

### Implementation plan

- [X] `InjectionLocationDetector.Search` should return `InjectionLocations` and `error` ([merge request](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/825))
- [x] The caller of the `Search` should log on `WARN` that the injection failed, and state that the scan will continue ([merge request](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/826/))
- [x] `InjectionLocation.Modify` should return `error` ([merge request](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/832))
- [x] The caller of the `Modify` should log on `WARN` that the injection failed, and state that the scan will continue ([merge request](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/834))
- [x] For all `InjectionLocationDetector` implementations, replace silent handling (return nil, or empty slice) with an `errors.Wrap` error ([merge request](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/827))
- [x] For all `InjectionLocation` implementations, replace silent handling (return nil, or empty slice) with an `errors.Wrap` error ([merge request](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/834))

title: Create a binary response body matcher
description:
### Problem

Certain active checks need to inspect the start of a binary response to determine what kind of file it is. An example is [552.2](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/365418), which needs to check for zipped file responses.

The response body matcher is only designed to work with text based searches and therefore excludes binary response bodies.

### Proposal

- Create a new response body matcher that always runs, regardless of the content-type header, or the inspected response body content.
- The `expression` the matcher uses to check content should be interpreted as a HEX string, not a regular expression.
- By default, the matcher should only check on the first 512 bytes of content. This is to ensure large file downloads do not add significant time to the scan.
- Check definition authors should be able to override the bytes to search limit.

Suggested YAML check definition:

```yaml
type: "match"
location: "response_body"
expression: "7573746172003030"
binary: true
byte_limit: 512
```

### Reference

Suggested in the following MR discussion https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/dast-cwe-checks/-/merge_requests/156#note_1088234402

### Implementation Plan

- [x] [Create a new type, `BinaryResponseBodyMatcher`. Given a hex string, search the response body bytes for a match](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/860)
- [x] [Add a default search limit of 512 bytes](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/dast-cwe-checks/-/merge_requests/194)
- [x] [Allow the limit to be overridden in the constructor option arguments](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/873)
- [x] [If there is no response, or the response has no body return `NotApplicableToMatch`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/860)
- [x] [If there is a match, create a byte matched value of the response](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/860)
- [x] [Add a unit test](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/860)
- [x] [Parsing `YamlMatch` matchers should parse `binary` and `byte_limit`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/873)
- [x] [If binary is `true`, a `BinaryResponseBodyMatcher` type should be created instead of `ResponseBodyMatcher`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/873)
- [x] [If `byte_limit` is included, it should be used as the limit for the matcher](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/873)

title: RPM `filelists.xml` updater
description:
## Proposal

The `filelists.xml` RPM repository metadata file contains a list of files for each package in the repository (or in our case, the project). Each time a new `.rpm` file is uploaded, we need to update this repository file. 

In this issue, we create a service that can update the `filelists.xml` given a package, a list of files, and any other relevant metadata that needs to be written to the `filelists.xml` file. The data to update this file will be coming from the service defined in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/372648.

title: `.rpm` filelist metadata extraction service
description:
## Proposal

Users can upload `.rpm` packages. When these files are uploaded, we need to be able to extract the list of files contained in them and update the `filelists.xml` repository metadata file. 

In this issue, we should create a service that takes a `.rpm` file and returns that list of files.

title: Extract `complete?` from `Pipeline#has_reports?` to the callers
description:
## Objective

To extract `pipeline.complete?` from within [`Pipeline#has_reports?`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/9a53af6f3473dd46cdf97eeda5cf4ba569aa1898/app/models/ci/pipeline.rb#L1076-1082) to the respective callers, so that the feature flag can be enabled and cleaned up.

| Caller location                                                          | code                                                                                                               | report type        |
|-------------------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|--------------------|
| app/models/merge_request.rb:1568                                  | actual_head_pipeline&.has_reports?(Ci::JobArtifact.of_report_type(:test))                                          | test               |
 | app/models/merge_request.rb:1598                                  | actual_head_pipeline.present? && actual_head_pipeline.has_reports?(Ci::JobArtifact.of_report_type(:accessibility)) | accessibility      |
 | app/models/merge_request.rb:1606                                  | actual_head_pipeline&.has_reports?(Ci::JobArtifact.of_report_type(:terraform))                                     | terraform          |
 | app/models/merge_request.rb:1646                                  | actual_head_pipeline&.has_reports?(Ci::JobArtifact.of_report_type(:codequality))                                   | codequality        |
 | app/models/merge_request.rb:1696                                  | !!actual_head_pipeline&.has_reports?(::Ci::JobArtifact.of_report_type(:sast))                                      | sast               |
 | app/models/merge_request.rb:1700                                  | !!actual_head_pipeline&.has_reports?(::Ci::JobArtifact.of_report_type(:secret_detection))                          | secret_detection   |
 | app/services/ci/job_artifacts/track_artifact_report_service.rb:13 | if pipeline.has_reports?(Ci::JobArtifact.of_report_type(report))                                                   | multiple           |
 | app/views/projects/pipelines/_with_tabs.html.haml:45              | has_test_report: @pipeline.has_reports?(Ci::JobArtifact.of_report_type(:test)).to_s,                               | test               |
 | ee/app/models/ee/merge_request.rb:205                             | !!actual_head_pipeline&.has_reports?(::Ci::JobArtifact.security_reports)                                           | security reports   |
 | ee/app/models/ee/merge_request.rb:209                             | !!actual_head_pipeline&.has_reports?(::Ci::JobArtifact.of_report_type(:dependency_list))                           | dependency_list    |
 | ee/app/models/ee/merge_request.rb:219                             | !!actual_head_pipeline&.has_reports?(::Ci::JobArtifact.of_report_type(:license_scanning))                          | license_scanning   |
 | ee/app/models/ee/merge_request.rb:223                             | !!actual_head_pipeline&.has_reports?(::Ci::JobArtifact.of_report_type(:container_scanning))                        | container_scanning |
 | ee/app/models/ee/merge_request.rb:233                             | !!actual_head_pipeline&.has_reports?(::Ci::JobArtifact.of_report_type(:dast))                                      | dast               |
 | ee/app/models/ee/merge_request.rb:260                             | !!actual_head_pipeline&.has_reports?(::Ci::JobArtifact.of_report_type(:metrics))                                   | metrics            |
 | ee/app/models/ee/merge_request.rb:270                             | !!actual_head_pipeline&.has_reports?(::Ci::JobArtifact.of_report_type(:coverage_fuzzing))                          | coverage_fuzzing   |
 | ee/app/models/ee/merge_request.rb:280                             | !!actual_head_pipeline&.has_reports?(::Ci::JobArtifact.of_report_type(:api_fuzzing))                               | api_fuzzing        |
 
This is required in order for the rollout https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/367027 to continue.

### Example of changes needed

`app/models/merge_request.rb:1568`

Before:
```rb
  def has_test_reports?
    actual_head_pipeline&.has_reports?(Ci::JobArtifact.of_report_type(:test))
  end
```

After:
```rb
  def has_test_reports?
    actual_head_pipeline&.complete? && actual_head_pipeline&.has_reports?(Ci::JobArtifact.of_report_type(:test))
  end
```

title: Trigger mergeRequestMergeStatusUpdated when all approvals are reset
description:
### Problem to solve

We want the merge widget to show updated status when all approvals are reset.

#### Testing
Unit tests if required. Add/update `spec/features` as part of this issue:  https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/372515
