title: Make it clear in the logs how authentication verification works
description:
### Problem

The DAST team has handled multiple support requests from clients who have been confused about how DAST authentication verification works.

### Proposal

Make it more explicit in the logs how verification works.

### Implementation plan

- [x] Add `SelfDescribing` to the `PageSpecification`
  - [x] Each page specification implementation should implement `Describe()`. Please log informative fields, for example, `HasSelector`: `return "has selector " + hasSelector.selector.Describe()`
- [x] Remove all will verify debug logs, e.g. `DBG AUTH  Will verify login attempts ...` 
- [x] Add a `Str` property to the information message `Verifying user login attempt`. Name it `strategy`, value should be the `Describe` of the logged in page specification
- [x] Remove `finding selector` log from `HasSelector`
- [x] Update remaining log message in `HasSelector` to have the module `LogAuthentication`
- [x] Update log messages in `IsAtURL` to have the module `LogAuthentication`
- [x] Update log messages in `HasAutoDetectedLoginForm` to have the module `LogAuthentication`
- [x] Update log messages in `HasAutoDetectedLoginForm` to start with a lower case letter
- [x] Run some manual tests, viewing the log for both successful and failed authentication attempts. Verify the log is readable and gives the user enough information on INFO to understand what is happening
  - [x] Verify log messages start with a lower case letter
- [x] See if there is a better way to log randomness constraint

title: Avatars in comments cards are 1px off in MR timeline view
description:
The MR comments' avatars are slightly (1px) off on the timeline, when compared to the timeline vertical line.

### Screenshots

![image](/uploads/d3553c571575856a686e6cf885c3e74f/image.png)

<details><summary>Tragic re-enactment to better reflect the off-by-pixel issue (expand)</summary>
![Screenshot_2022-09-05_at_19.41.49](/uploads/ddea9ba6fcf5b4310d654805089f67ef/Screenshot_2022-09-05_at_19.41.49.png)
</details>

### Steps to reproduce

Open an (existing) MR on "Overview" tab and scroll to the timeline / comments. Note the slightly off centered avatars.


### Context

The timeline vertical line was moved `1px` left in this MR: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/92679/diffs#79ea7020ff2bdc6a515cb8c8bf815c6e3e436386_33_32 to be better aligned with timeline _icons_, while avatars in timeline comments stayed at the same position. So now it seems that the _avatars_ are `1px` off to the right.

### Expected behaviour

Avatars and icons are centered / aligned with the vertical line.

title: Outdated merge request data can be used when getting merge requests through  REST API
description:
This potential issue popped up in MR discussion linked below: it seems we cache merge requests in REST API and the cache key is build from a few set of MR attributes/associations. But it looks like the same problem may occur whenever any other attribute/association (which is exposed through the API and is not part of the key) is changed.

The following discussion from !96860 should be addressed:

- [ ] @jprovaznik started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/96860#note_1088002892):  (+1 comment)

    > If I understand it correctly, it means that this caching approach assumes that **all** of attributes which are exposed and can potentially change should be part of the cache key, right?
    > 
    > Wouldn't we have exactly same problem when some other exposed attributes are changed? For example what happens if [labels](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/api/entities/merge_request_basic.rb#L36) are changed? It almost looks like we would keep presenting cached/invalid list of labels because labels are not part of this key?

title: Workhorse: support google as object storage provider
description:
## :fire: Situation

If we look at the object storage configuration on Workhorse, we can see that only `aws` and `azure` are supported.

It's sad that `google` is not supported since it's what is used on ~"gitlab.com".

That support would allow to use the workhorse internal client to upload files when in [direct upload](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/uploads/#direct-upload) mode.

By using the internal client, we can have some :bell: and whistles for free. For example, the workhorse internal client will make use of [resumable uploads](https://cloud.google.com/storage/docs/resumable-uploads) when a large file is encountered.

Also, by using the internal client, it's easier to support additional [encryption modes](https://cloud.google.com/storage/docs/encryption) such as KMS or even customer supplied keys.

## :fire_engine: Solution

To support the workhorse internal `google` client, we need a few changes:

1. Update workhorse to load a `google` client when the object storage configuration is describing that.
1. Update rails so that in direct upload mode + `google` provider, we instruct workhorse to use its client.
1. If I'm not wrong, we need to update https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/omnibus-gitlab so that the rails object storage configuration with `google` creates the appropriate workhorse configuration.

It is advised to use a ~"feature flag" for this.

title: Add instrumentation for cache metrics
description:
### Problem

We want to collect metrics about cache keys to know the hit rate and performance of the cache. Currently, we have multiple implementations for it but no single library to set up them consistently. 

### Epic

This work contributes to the https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-com/gl-infra/-/epics/763+ epic but cannot be directly linked as the Epic was created in `gitlab-com`.

### Solution

* Create a library to setup common labels and provide metrics methods to caching classes

### Requirements

We could initialize it with a bunch of stuff we want to expose as
labels on all metrics:

- feature_category: not from the caller, but manually set by the
  "owner" of the cache  
- cache_identifier: Where to find the cache definition for example
  `ProtectedBranches::CacheService#fetch`  
- backing_resource: What resource is the cache generation using mostly
  (database, gitaly, cpu, ...)  
- caller_id: The caller id from the application context

We could potentially allow callers to pass extra labels if need be.

[source](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/96382#note_1080699618)


### Prototype

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/96382/diffs

title: [Feature flag] Enable dora_configuration feature flag
description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Feature flag] Enable description of feature -->

## Summary

This issue is to rollout [the feature](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/96561#note_1088054961) on production,
that is currently behind the `dora_configuration` feature flag.

<!-- Short description of what the feature is about and link to relevant other issues. -->

## Owners

- Team: Optimize
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_manage_optimize`
- Best individual to reach out to: @pshutsin
- PM: @hsnir1 

## Rollout Steps

### Rollout on non-production environments

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- [x] Enable the feature globally on non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true --dev --staging --staging-ref`
- [x] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.
      The best environment to validate the feature in is [staging-canary](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/#staging-canary)
      as this is the first environment deployed to. Note you will need to make sure you are configured to use canary as outlined [here](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/canary-stage/)
      when accessing the staging environment in order to make sure you are testing appropriately.

### Specific rollout on production

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to both production and canary.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- If you're using [project-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab,gitlab-org/gitlab-foss,gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com <feature-flag-name> true`
- If you're using [group-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --group=gitlab-org,gitlab-com <feature-flag-name> true`
- If you're using [user-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --user=<your-username> <feature-flag-name> true`
- [ ] Verify that the feature works on the specific entries. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Preparation before global rollout

- [ ] Check if the feature flag change needs to be accompanied with a
  [change management issue](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/change-management/#feature-flags-and-the-change-management-process).
  Cross link the issue here if it does.
- [ ] Ensure that you or a representative in development can be available for at least 2 hours after feature flag updates in production.
  If a different developer will be covering, or an exception is needed, please inform the oncall SRE by using the `@sre-oncall` Slack alias.
- [ ] Ensure that documentation has been updated ([More info](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature_flags.html#features-that-became-enabled-by-default)).
- [ ] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com. 
- [ ] Ensure that any breaking changes have been announced following the [release post process](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/blog/release-posts/#deprecations-removals-and-breaking-changes) to ensure GitLab customers are aware.
- [ ] Notify `#support_gitlab-com` and your team channel ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#communicate-the-change)).

### Global rollout on production

For visibility, all `/chatops` commands that target production should be executed in the `#production` slack channel and cross-posted (with the command results) to the responsible team's slack channel (`#g_TEAM_NAME`).

- [ ] [Incrementally roll out](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#process) the feature.
  - If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform **actor-based** rollout.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage> --actors`
  - If the feature flag in code does **NOT** have [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform time-based rollout (**random** rollout).
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage> --random`
  - Enable the feature globally on production environment.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true`
- [ ] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) that the feature has been globally enabled.
- [ ] Wait for [at least one day for the verification term](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release).

### (Optional) Release the feature with the feature flag

If you're still unsure whether the feature is [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release)
but want to release it in the current milestone, you can change the default state of the feature flag to be enabled.
To do so, follow these steps:

- [ ] Create a merge request with the following changes. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [ ] Set the `default_enabled` attribute in [the feature flag definition](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-flag-definition-and-validation) to `true`.
    - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the default-enabling MR has been included in the release package.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the monthly release was tagged](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run release check <merge-request-url> <milestone>`
- [ ] Consider cleaning up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel. Otherwise these settings may override the default enabled.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --dev --staging --staging-ref --production`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [ ] Set the next milestone to this rollout issue for scheduling [the flag removal](#release-the-feature).
- [ ] (Optional) You can [create a separate issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) for scheduling the steps below to [Release the feature](#release-the-feature).
    - [ ] Set the title to "[Feature flag] Cleanup `<feature-flag-name>`".
    - [ ] Execute the `/copy_metadata <this-rollout-issue-link>` quick action to copy the labels from this rollout issue.
    - [ ] Link this rollout issue as a related issue.
    - [ ] Close this rollout issue.

**WARNING:** This approach has the downside that it makes it difficult for us to
[clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) the flag.
For example, on-premise users could disable the feature on their GitLab instance. But when you
remove the flag at some point, they suddenly see the feature as enabled and they can't roll it back
to the previous behavior. To avoid this potential breaking change, use this approach only for urgent
matters.

### Release the feature

After the feature has been [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release),
the [clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up)
should be done as soon as possible to permanently enable the feature and reduce complexity in the
codebase.

You can either [create a follow-up issue for Feature Flag Cleanup](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) or use the checklist below in this same issue.

<!-- The checklist here is to help stakeholders keep track of the feature flag status -->
- [ ] Create a merge request to remove `<feature-flag-name>` feature flag. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [ ] Remove all references to the feature flag from the codebase.
    - [ ] Remove the YAML definitions for the feature from the repository.
    - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the cleanup MR has been included in the release package.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the monthly release was tagged](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run release check <merge-request-url> <milestone>`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [ ] If not already done, clean up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --dev --staging --staging-ref --production`
- [ ] Close this rollout issue.

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> false
```

title: Use `DestroyBatchService` in `Ci::Build#erase_erasable_artifacts`
description:
Currently, `Ci::Build#erase_erasable_artifacts!` uses `job_artifacts.destroy_all` to delete all artifacts within the build.

Given the intricacies of artifact deletion, we should avoid having multiple ways to delete a batch of artifacts and have a single service that handles this. We already have `Ci::JobArtifacts::DestroyBatchService` so let's use this here as well instead of `destroy_all`.

Similar to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/369132

title: Investigate if the index_environments_on_name_varchar_pattern_ops index is being used and still needed
description:
Follow up from the https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/96774

It looked like the index is still being used, not much though:

https://thanos-query.ops.gitlab.net/graph?g0.expr=sum(rate(pg_stat_user_indexes_idx_scan%7Benv%3D%22gprd%22%2C%20indexrelname%3D%22index_environments_on_name_varchar_pattern_ops%22%7D%5B1h%5D))&g0.tab=0&g0.stacked=0&g0.range_input=1w&g0.max_source_resolution=0s&g0.deduplicate=1&g0.partial_response=1&g0.store_matches=%5B%5D&g0.end_input=2022-09-05%2008%3A02%3A03&g0.moment_input=2022-09-05%2008%3A02%3A03

Once https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/96774 is merged it would be nice to check and see if the index is being used. If not, we can remove it and save some space/time on DML queries.

title: Container Registry cleanup tags service improvement
description:
## :fire: Problem

Follow up of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/96513#note_1086787123

Cleanup tags services build a list of tags to delete out of the parameters it receives.

Currently, this list is managed with an instance variable which makes the code harder to read.

## :fire_engine: Solution

Switch to local variables. Each "step" should receive the current list and return the new one.

:warning: keep all the bang functions used. They help to _not_ duplicate the list.

We have two services:
* `app/services/projects/container_repository/cleanup_tags_service.rb`
* `app/services/projects/container_repository/gitlab/cleanup_tags_service.rb`

title: Follow-up from "Destroy merge request diffs in batches"
description:
The following discussions from !96455 should be addressed:

- [x] @drew started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/96455#note_1086858130): 

    > We have a `BATCH_SIZE = 100` constant in this class, should we use the same one here?

- [x] @drew started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/96455#note_1086860084): 

    > the yielded object here is just a relation, not any particular IDs of the records in the relation:
    > 
    > ```
    >    190:       project.merge_requests.each_batch(column: :iid, of: mr_batch_size) do |relation_ids|
    >    191:         byebug
    > => 192:         loop do
    >    193:           deleted_rows = MergeRequestDiff
    >    194:             .where(merge_request_id: relation_ids)
    >    195:             .limit(delete_batch_size)
    >    196:             .delete_all
    > (byebug) relation_ids
    > #<ActiveRecord::AssociationRelation [#<MergeRequest id:1 user1/project1!1>]>
    > ```
    > 
    > And the queries use an `IN (subquery)` structure no matter what:
    > 
    > ```
    > (byebug) puts MergeRequestDiff.where(merge_request: relation_ids).to_sql
    > SELECT "merge_request_diffs".* FROM "merge_request_diffs" WHERE "merge_request_diffs"."merge_request_id" IN (SELECT "merge_requests"."id" FROM "merge_requests" WHERE "merge_requests"."target_project_id" = 1 AND "merge_requests"."iid" >= 1)
    > 
    > (byebug) puts MergeRequestDiff.where(merge_request_id: relation_ids).to_sql
    > SELECT "merge_request_diffs".* FROM "merge_request_diffs" WHERE "merge_request_diffs"."merge_request_id" IN (SELECT "merge_requests"."id" FROM "merge_requests" WHERE "merge_requests"."target_project_id" = 1 AND "merge_requests"."iid" >= 1)
    > ```
    > 
    > So it might be clearer to not use `_id` in the naming here?
    > 
    > ```suggestion:-3+0
    >       project.merge_requests.each_batch(column: :iid, of: mr_batch_size) do |relation|
    >         loop do
    >           deleted_rows = MergeRequestDiff
    >             .where(merge_request: relation)
    > ```
    > 
    > WDYT?

title: Trigger mergeRequestMergeStatusUpdated when discussion is marked or unmarked as resolved
description:
### Problem to solve

We want the merge widget to show updated status when MR discussions get all resolved or when an MR discussion gets unresolved.

### Proposal

Trigger the `mergeRequestMergeStatusUpdated` subscription when:
- all MR discussions get resolved
- an MR discussion gets unresolved

We can trigger the subscription in `Discussions#ResolveService` (check for `MergeRequest#mergeable_discussions_state?`) and `Discussions::UnresolveService`.

### Availability and testing
Recommended to add a feature spec for:
- when all discussions get resolved
- when all discussions are resolved, unresolve one discussion

title: Trigger mergeRequestMergeStatusUpdated when MR is approved or unapproved
description:
### Problem to solve

We want the merge widget to show updated status when MR is approved (and MR is considered as approved for merging) or unapproved.

### Proposal

Trigger the `mergeRequestMergeStatusUpdated` subscription when:
- MR is approved and all approval rules are considered approved
- MR is unapproved

We can trigger the subscription in `MergeRequests::ApprovalService` and `MergeRequests::RemoveApprovalService`.

title: Trigger mergeRequestMergeStatusUpdated when MR is closed
description:
### Problem to solve

We want the merge widget to show updated status when MR is closed or reopened.

### Proposal

Trigger the `mergeRequestMergeStatusUpdated` subscription when:
- MR is closed.
- ~MR is re-opened~ (not needed anymore since we transition `merge_status` to `unchecked` on reopen and we already have a trigger when that happens).

We can trigger the subscription in `MergeRequests::CloseService`.

title: Trigger mergeRequestMergeStatusUpdated when merge_status changes
description:
### Problem to solve

When mergeability check runs for a MR, the `merge_status` changes if:

- MR is marked as unchecked (`unchecked`)
- a job is enqueued to check the mergeability of the MR (`checking`)
- when mergeability check runs and MR has conflicts (`cannot_be_merged`)
- when mergeability check runs and MR is mergeable (`can_be_merged`)

Whenever these scenarios happen, we want to update the merge widget in real-time to show updated state.

### Proposal

Trigger the `mergeRequestMergeStatusUpdated` when the scenarios above occurs so ~frontend will be able to show the updated merge status on merge widget.

For the `unchecked` statue, we can trigger the subscription in places where `MergeRequest#mark_as_unchecked` is called.

For the `checking` state, we can trigger the subscription in `MergeRequests::MergeabilityCheckService#async_execute` after the `MergeRequest#mark_as_checking` call.

For the `cannot_be_merged` and `can_be_merged` statuses, we can trigger the subscription in `MergeRequests::MergeabilityCheckService#update_merge_status` depending on the outcome (whether it's mergeable or not).

title: Container Scanning missing nil check for OS package detection
description:
### Summary

When Container Scanning runs on a container image where OS package information has been removed, the [job fails](https://gitlab.com/greg/3895/-/jobs/2976481689#L342) with `undefined method `map' for nil:NilClass`

<details><summary>Click for full backtrace</summary>

```
[ERROR] [container-scanning]    undefined method `map' for nil:NilClass
[ERROR] [container-scanning]    /usr/local/bundle/gems/gcs-5.1.19/lib/gcs/dependency_list_converter.rb:79:in `convert_dependencies'
/usr/local/bundle/gems/gcs-5.1.19/lib/gcs/dependency_list_converter.rb:40:in `block in convert'
/usr/local/bundle/gems/gcs-5.1.19/lib/gcs/dependency_list_converter.rb:36:in `map'
/usr/local/bundle/gems/gcs-5.1.19/lib/gcs/dependency_list_converter.rb:36:in `convert'
/usr/local/bundle/gems/gcs-5.1.19/lib/gcs/plugin/dependency_scan.rb:11:in `convert'
/usr/local/bundle/gems/gcs-5.1.19/lib/gcs/scan.rb:26:in `scan_image'
/usr/local/bundle/gems/gcs-5.1.19/lib/gcs/cli.rb:15:in `block in scan'
/usr/local/bundle/gems/gcs-5.1.19/lib/gcs/cli.rb:14:in `map'
/usr/local/bundle/gems/gcs-5.1.19/lib/gcs/cli.rb:14:in `scan'
/usr/local/bundle/gems/thor-1.2.1/lib/thor/command.rb:27:in `run'
/usr/local/bundle/gems/thor-1.2.1/lib/thor/invocation.rb:127:in `invoke_command'
/usr/local/bundle/gems/thor-1.2.1/lib/thor.rb:392:in `dispatch'
/usr/local/bundle/gems/thor-1.2.1/lib/thor/base.rb:485:in `start'
/usr/local/bundle/gems/gcs-5.1.19/exe/gtcs:11:in `<top (required)>'
/usr/local/bundle/bin/gtcs:23:in `load'
/usr/local/bundle/bin/gtcs:23:in `<main>'
Uploading artifacts for failed job
Uploading artifacts...
gl-container-scanning-report.json: found 1 matching files and directories 
Uploading artifacts as "container_scanning" to coordinator... 201 Created  id=2976481689 responseStatus=201 Created token=D41SchyQ
Uploading artifacts...
WARNING: gl-dependency-scanning-report.json: no matching files. Ensure that the artifact path is relative to the working directory 
ERROR: No files to upload                          
Cleaning up project directory and file based variables
ERROR: Job failed: exit code 1
```

</details>

### Steps to reproduce

1. Fork, clone, copy, or import https://gitlab.com/greg/3895
2. Trigger a pipeline
3. Verify that `container_scanning` job failed.

### Example Project

https://gitlab.com/greg/3895

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Job fails and errors out with `undefined method `map' for nil:NilClass`

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Add a nil check that alows the job to complete with a warning that no OS packages were found.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

https://gitlab.com/greg/3895/-/jobs/2976481689#L342

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com

### Possible fixes

Add a `nil` check when/if no OS packages are found.

I think we'll want to add it here: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/container-scanning/-/blob/master/lib/gcs/dependency_list_converter.rb

title: Geo secondary UI redirects to primary UI after Okta SSO
description:
### Summary

We upgraded our geo configured gitlab EE instances. The upgrade path was from gitlab-ee=14.10.5-ee.0, then to gitlab-ee=15.0.5-ee.0, then to  gitlab-ee=15.1.6-ee.0, and finally to gitlab-ee=15.2.4-ee.0. 

Before the upgrade, we could access both our primary and our geo nodes UIs. After the upgrade, 
when navigating to our geo node's URL, the callback URL after Okta authentication redirects back to the primary node's UI. The geo node's UI is inaccessible, but replication is happening on the backend. 

### Steps to reproduce

1. Navigate to geo node's URL
2. Authenticate through Okta
3. The authenticated session is always the primary node's UI. 

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

After navigating to geo node's URL, the authentication redirects you to the primary node's UI. 

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

After navigating to geo node's URL, the authentication redirects you to the geo node's UI.

### Relevant details

Internal links only
[ZD](https://support.gitlab.com/hc/en-us/requests/321645)

title: Consider increasing the number of specs in rspec foss-impact job in CI
description:
## Challenge

See [this slack thread](https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/CMA7DQJRX/p1662131304291319).

> It seems that the failure rate of `rspec foss-impact` has increased from around 8% to 40% since https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/96152 was merged on 2022-08-31.

When `rspec foss-impact` job fails with `This job is intentionally failed because there are more than 20 FOSS test files matched` reason, the current workaround is that the author needs to trigger an entire new pipeline with the ~pipeline:run-as-if-foss label.

## Proposal

Temporarily allow `rspec foss-impact` job to fail and raise the number of specs to run from `20` to `40` and see if duration is acceptable.

title: [Feature flag] Rollout of `skip_default_scope_for_events`
description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Feature flag] Enable description of feature -->

## Summary

This issue is to rollout [the feature](ISSUE LINK) on production,
that is currently behind the `<feature-flag-name>` feature flag.

<!-- Short description of what the feature is about and link to relevant other issues. -->

## Owners

- Team: Optimize
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_manage_optimize`
- Best individual to reach out to: ahegyi
- PM: blabuschagne

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

No change in application behaviour.

### When is the feature viable?

No errors were observed related to the `events` table.

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

Statement timeouts, and slow database queries.

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/api-rails-controller/api-rails-controller?orgId=1&var-PROMETHEUS_DS=Global&var-environment=gprd&var-stage=main&var-controller=Grape&var-action=GET%20%2Fapi%2Fprojects&var-action=GET%20%2Fapi%2Fevents

### What can we check for monitoring production after rollouts?

_Consider adding links to check for Sentry errors, Production logs for 5xx, 302s, etc._

## Rollout Steps

### Rollout on non-production environments

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to non-production environments.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- [x] Enable the feature globally on non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true --dev --staging --staging-ref`
- [x] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.
      The best environment to validate the feature in is [staging-canary](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/#staging-canary)
      as this is the first environment deployed to. Note you will need to make sure you are configured to use canary as outlined [here](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/canary-stage/)
      when accessing the staging environment in order to make sure you are testing appropriately.

### Specific rollout on production

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to both production and canary.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- If you're using [project-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab,gitlab-org/gitlab-foss,gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com <feature-flag-name> true`
- If you're using [group-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --group=gitlab-org,gitlab-com <feature-flag-name> true`
- If you're using [user-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --user=<your-username> <feature-flag-name> true`
- [ ] Verify that the feature works on the specific entries. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Preparation before global rollout

- [ ] Check if the feature flag change needs to be accompanied with a
  [change management issue](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/change-management/#feature-flags-and-the-change-management-process).
  Cross link the issue here if it does.
- [ ] Ensure that you or a representative in development can be available for at least 2 hours after feature flag updates in production.
  If a different developer will be covering, or an exception is needed, please inform the oncall SRE by using the `@sre-oncall` Slack alias.
- [ ] Ensure that documentation has been updated ([More info](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature_flags.html#features-that-became-enabled-by-default)).
- [ ] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com. 
- [ ] Ensure that any breaking changes have been announced following the [release post process](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/blog/release-posts/#deprecations-removals-and-breaking-changes) to ensure GitLab customers are aware.
- [ ] Notify `#support_gitlab-com` and your team channel ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#communicate-the-change)).

### Global rollout on production

For visibility, all `/chatops` commands that target production should be executed in the `#production` slack channel and cross-posted (with the command results) to the responsible team's slack channel (`#g_TEAM_NAME`).

- [ ] [Incrementally roll out](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#process) the feature.
  - If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform **actor-based** rollout.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage> --actors`
  - If the feature flag in code does **NOT** have [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform time-based rollout (**random** rollout).
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage> --random`
  - Enable the feature globally on production environment.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true`
- [ ] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) that the feature has been globally enabled.
- [ ] Wait for [at least one day for the verification term](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release).

### (Optional) Release the feature with the feature flag

If you're still unsure whether the feature is [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release)
but want to release it in the current milestone, you can change the default state of the feature flag to be enabled.
To do so, follow these steps:

- [ ] Create a merge request with the following changes. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [ ] Set the `default_enabled` attribute in [the feature flag definition](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-flag-definition-and-validation) to `true`.
    - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the default-enabling MR has been included in the release package.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the monthly release was tagged](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run release check <merge-request-url> <milestone>`
- [ ] Consider cleaning up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel. Otherwise these settings may override the default enabled.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --dev --staging --staging-ref --production`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [ ] Set the next milestone to this rollout issue for scheduling [the flag removal](#release-the-feature).
- [ ] (Optional) You can [create a separate issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) for scheduling the steps below to [Release the feature](#release-the-feature).
    - [ ] Set the title to "[Feature flag] Cleanup `<feature-flag-name>`".
    - [ ] Execute the `/copy_metadata <this-rollout-issue-link>` quick action to copy the labels from this rollout issue.
    - [ ] Link this rollout issue as a related issue.
    - [ ] Close this rollout issue.

**WARNING:** This approach has the downside that it makes it difficult for us to
[clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) the flag.
For example, on-premise users could disable the feature on their GitLab instance. But when you
remove the flag at some point, they suddenly see the feature as enabled and they can't roll it back
to the previous behavior. To avoid this potential breaking change, use this approach only for urgent
matters.

### Release the feature

After the feature has been [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release),
the [clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up)
should be done as soon as possible to permanently enable the feature and reduce complexity in the
codebase.

You can either [create a follow-up issue for Feature Flag Cleanup](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) or use the checklist below in this same issue.

<!-- The checklist here is to help stakeholders keep track of the feature flag status -->
- [ ] Create a merge request to remove `<feature-flag-name>` feature flag. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [ ] Remove all references to the feature flag from the codebase.
    - [ ] Remove the YAML definitions for the feature from the repository.
    - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the cleanup MR has been included in the release package.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the monthly release was tagged](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run release check <merge-request-url> <milestone>`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [ ] If not already done, clean up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --dev --staging --staging-ref --production`
- [ ] Close this rollout issue.

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> false
```

We have two Slack integrations that we want to merge into one: 

- [Slack Notifications](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/integrations/slack.html) integration (model: `Integrations::Slack`).
- [Slack Application](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/integrations/gitlab_slack_application.html) integration (model: `Integrations::GitlabSlackApplication`).

The Slack Notifications integration allows users to subscribe to events in GitLab and receive notifications of those events in a Slack channel.

The Slack Application integration allows users to use the features of the GitLab Slack App (currently limited to slash commands, but rapidly being built out!).

We want to merge the [Slack Notifications](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/integrations/slack.html) integration into the [Slack Application](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/integrations/gitlab_slack_application.html) integration, so users need to only enable the Slack Application integration in order to use both the features of the Slack App and Slack notifications.

## Risks

This kind of refactoring can uncover hidden complexity that _might_ mean the weight of the issue should be increased once it has started.

If it's necessary to increase the weight then please communicate this to the PM and EM on this issue.

## Proposal

The work for this is broken into 2 issues, with https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/373321 being the second part. 

### Backend

Although this hasn't been technically verified, it should be possible to:

- Change `Integrations::GitlabSlackApplication` to inherit from `BaseChatNotification`.
- Share code between `Integrations::Slack` and `Integrations::GitlabSlackApplication` by wrapping the shared code in a new module they both mixin.

This would port the ~backend functionality of the Slack Notifications integration into the Slack Application integration.

##### No-op when notifying

For this iteration, the actual posting of notifications to Slack will be a no-op (meaning, for this iteration the integration will not post a notification, but will still technically do everything up to that point), and https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/373321 will implement this next step.

##### Feature flag

The change should be behind a feature flag that will not be enabled on production until https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/373321. The notification settings form should not display when the feature flag is disabled, so for this iteration, customers should see no changes.

### Frontend

TODO We need to understand the ~frontend part of this and the work involved in having the Slack Notifications settings display on the Slack Application integration form.

### Design

| Step | Image |
|------|-------|
| Put a warning banner for everyone | ![Frame_34](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/faaa1b77a9e4b79b2faba2a481e417c2/Frame_34.png) |

title: Branch rules MVC: Display branch rules details
description:
### Description

Displays details of the branch rules. This is a readonly view.

### Scope

* Display branch name/pattern
* Display matching branches
* Display branch protections
* Display merge request approvals
* Display status checks
* Navigate to the current settings sections to provide a way to edit.
    - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/372362#note_1088241391
* Details page URL will be under `/-/settings/repository/branch_rules`
    - Will use a query parameter to specify a particular branch rule
    - Default will link to ???
    - If there are no branch rules we should display an empty state (TBD)

### Mockups

| Form | In Page | All branches | All protected branches |
| ------ | ------ | ------ | ------ |
| ![image](/uploads/662ab2ecae34a0a3dd018fea52998030/image.png) | ![image](/uploads/33b3d7d437e66eded21b794802d6dd33/image.png) | ![image](/uploads/dd2e42f88ebc14731cd41ac7fc9d4bca/image.png) | ![image](/uploads/fc3baa142b313b36bb7e918aee3ac748/image.png) |

- Changed the title from "View branch rules" to "Branch rules details"

### Questions

- [x] **question:** When viewing the details page, what is the URL? https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/372362#note_1085468757
    - _Answer_: `<project>/-/settings/repository/branch_rules?branch=BRANCH_RULE_NAME/BRANCH_RULE_PATTERN`
- [x] **question:** Are we able to display the matching branches in the details view or should we link off the matching branch page? https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/372362#note_1085475210
    - _Answer_: Linking off to matching branch page
- [x] **question**: Should this issue include the work to navigate to the respective settings section of each branch rule section? https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/372362#note_1088203462
    - _Answer_: We can navigate to a page with expanded sections https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/372362#note_1088241391
- [ ] **question:** What might be the difference between selecting "All branches" vs "All protected branches"?

### Testing

Exploratory and regression testing in MRs, please ensure all tests still pass including `e2e:package-and-test`.

title: Incorrect "environments" API endpoint path in GitLab UI results in "There was an error fetching the environments information"
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "type::bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=type::bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

In GitLab 15.3.1, accessing `Setting -> CI/CD` on a group or subgroup page displays the error message "There was an error fetching the environments information."

The browser console indicates that the error is a `404` coming from trying to access `https://<my-host-dns>/api/v4/projects//environments`
Notice the missing `id` in the url path.

If `/api/v4/projects/19/environments` is used (for example) we get a correct `200` response.

Issue has been initially reported by a Premium customer: https://gitlab.zendesk.com/agent/tickets/321375 (internal ZD)

### Steps to reproduce

Accessing `Setting -> CI/CD` on a group or subgroup page displays the error message "There was an error fetching the environments information."

![Screenshot_1__1_](/uploads/04382a8974cca596f6fee5358dcce8a1/Screenshot_1__1_.png)


### What is the current *bug* behavior?

The `environments` api endpoint path seems to be constructed incorrectly (missing `id`) when accessing  `Groups -> Setting -> CI/CD` (a "There was an error fetching the environments information." error message is displayed in the UI)

![Screenshot_1](/uploads/ed19434f25d7f14ded20717fba9cacdd/Screenshot_1.png)


### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

The `environments` endpoint path should be correctly constructed in the  `Groups -> Setting -> CI/CD` page of the UI.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

<!-- Paste any relevant logs - please use code blocks (```) to format console output, logs, and code
 as it's tough to read otherwise. -->



### Possible fixes

<!-- If you can, link to the line of code that might be responsible for the problem. -->

title: Run `rspec foss-impact` as parallel jobs
description:
After https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/96152, we now detect a lot more FOSS test files based on MR changes.

That means the `rspec foss-impact` jobs has more chance to exit due to many test files detected (more than 20).

To solve that, there are a few options:

- Make it run in parallel so it just works
- Auto-detect this and run full FOSS by itself
- Somehow work around this and apply the label, fail the pipeline early, trigger another one, etc

My preference would be to run `rspec foss-impact` in parallel because it would allow to catch failures that could potentially break FOSS `master`, without the need to run the full test suite "as if foss".

I think it's better to favor `rspec foss-impact` over ~"pipeline:run-as-if-foss" (in terms of cost).

To optimize the number of parallelized jobs, we could use a child pipeline to dynamically set the number of nodes to run the job on.

title: Increase export batch_size
description:
Currently we use quite small batch_size (2 - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/import_export/json/streaming_serializer.rb#L9) when exporting resources. This is not ideal because then too many queries need to be done to load all project/group resources (and also preloading is not very effective as we preload per each batch).

From discussing this with @georgekoltsov (temporary slack thread: https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/CLX7WMSKW/p1662020004920209)
"I think batch size can be increased to its original number. If I recall correctly reducing the batch size was behind a feature flag in order to try help export a very big project for one customer. And when this feature flag got removed we changed the original value to a smaller one affecting everyone, So it makes sense to increase it back.

title: Require `schemes:` kwarg for Gitlab::URLBlocker.validate!
description:
Related to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/372165+

## Problem

A lot of people think that `Gitlab::URLBlocker.validate!` defaults to `schemes: %w[http https]` - It does not. It actually allows any scheme by default


### Proposal

Make `schemes:` kwarg mandatory

The alternative is that we make `schemes` default to `%w[http https]`, but we might be making an invalid assumption by doing so.

Unsure which group should action this.

title: [Feature flag] Rollout of `usage_data_ci_i_testing_test_report_uploaded`
description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Feature flag] Enable description of feature -->

## Summary

This issue is to rollout [Usage ping for artifacts:reports:junit](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/339720) on production,
that is currently behind the `usage_data_ci_i_testing_test_report_uploaded` feature flag.

<!-- Short description of what the feature is about and link to relevant other issues. -->

## Owners

- Team: Verify::Pipeline Insights
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_pipeline-insights`
- Best individual to reach out to: dbiryukov
- PM: shampton

## Stakeholders

<!--
Are there any other stages or teams involved that need to be kept in the loop?

- Name of a PM
- The Support Team
- The Delivery Team
-->

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

<!-- Describe the expected outcome when rolling out this feature -->

Expecting to get metrics online `MAU` for `Usage ping for artifacts:reports:junit` on `Sisense` dashboard.

Add a tracking event that fires when this artifact is uploaded by a pipeline. We should track user who triggered the pipeline and only increment by 1 for each pipeline, not each artifact.

### When is the feature viable?

When the [Service Ping](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/service_ping/) Metrics configuration would be online

We have to create a Sisense dashboard and [guide on how to create it](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/business-technology/data-team/programs/data-for-product-managers/#how-to-consume-data-at-gitlab).

<!-- What are the settings we need to configure in order to have this feature viable? -->


Example below:
 
1. We have to create a Sisense dashboard and [guide on how to create it](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/business-technology/data-team/programs/data-for-product-managers/#how-to-consume-data-at-gitlab).


### What might happen if this goes wrong?

<!-- Should the feature flag be turned off? Any MRs that need to be rolled back? Communication that needs to happen? What are some things you can think of that could go wrong - data loss or broken pages? -->

No metrics data is presented. In the worth scenario, we could block testing workers queue on `Ci::Pipeline`

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

[Monitor your metric guide.](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/service_ping/implement.html#verify-your-metric)

<!-- Which dashboards from https://dashboards.gitlab.net are most relevant? -->
_Consider mentioning checks for 5xx errors or other anomalies like an increase in redirects 
(302 HTTP response status)_

### What can we check for monitoring production after rollouts?

_Consider adding links to check for Sentry errors, Production logs for 5xx, 302s, etc._

## Rollout Steps

### Rollout on non-production environments

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- [x] Enable the feature globally on non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true --dev --staging --staging-ref`
- [x] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.
      The best environment to validate the feature in is [staging-canary](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/#staging-canary)
      as this is the first environment deployed to. Note you will need to make sure you are configured to use canary as outlined [here](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/canary-stage/)
      when accessing the staging environment in order to make sure you are testing appropriately.

### Specific rollout on production

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to both production and canary.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- If you're using [project-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab,gitlab-org/gitlab-foss,gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com <feature-flag-name> true`
- If you're using [group-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --group=gitlab-org,gitlab-com <feature-flag-name> true`
- If you're using [user-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --user=<your-username> <feature-flag-name> true`
- [ ] Verify that the feature works on the specific entries. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.
- [x] Global rollout For Service ping thins should be rollout globally `/chatops run feature set usage_data_ci_i_testing_test_report_uploaded true`

### Preparation before global rollout

- [x] Check if the feature flag change needs to be accompanied with a
  [change management issue](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/change-management/#feature-flags-and-the-change-management-process).
  Cross link the issue here if it does.
- [x] Ensure that you or a representative in development can be available for at least 2 hours after feature flag updates in production.
  If a different developer will be covering, or an exception is needed, please inform the oncall SRE by using the `@sre-oncall` Slack alias.
- [ ] Ensure that documentation has been updated ([More info](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature_flags.html#features-that-became-enabled-by-default)).
- [x] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com. 
- [x] Ensure that any breaking changes have been announced following the [release post process](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/blog/release-posts/#deprecations-removals-and-breaking-changes) to ensure GitLab customers are aware.
- [ ] Notify `#support_gitlab-com` and your team channel ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#communicate-the-change)).

### Global rollout on production

For visibility, all `/chatops` commands that target production should be executed in the `#production` slack channel and cross-posted (with the command results) to the responsible team's slack channel (`#g_TEAM_NAME`).

- [x] [Incrementally roll out](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#process) the feature.
  - If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform **actor-based** rollout.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage> --actors`
  - If the feature flag in code does **NOT** have [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform time-based rollout (**random** rollout).
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage> --random`
  - Enable the feature globally on production environment.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true`
- [x] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) that the feature has been globally enabled.
- [x] Wait for [at least one day for the verification term](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release).

### (Optional) Release the feature with the feature flag

If you're still unsure whether the feature is [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release)
but want to release it in the current milestone, you can change the default state of the feature flag to be enabled.
To do so, follow these steps:

- [ ] Create a merge request with the following changes. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [ ] Set the `default_enabled` attribute in [the feature flag definition](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-flag-definition-and-validation) to `true`.
    - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the default-enabling MR has been included in the release package.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the monthly release was tagged](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run release check <merge-request-url> <milestone>`
- [ ] Consider cleaning up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel. Otherwise these settings may override the default enabled.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --dev --staging --staging-ref --production`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [ ] Set the next milestone to this rollout issue for scheduling [the flag removal](#release-the-feature).
- [ ] (Optional) You can [create a separate issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) for scheduling the steps below to [Release the feature](#release-the-feature).
    - [ ] Set the title to "[Feature flag] Cleanup `<feature-flag-name>`".
    - [ ] Execute the `/copy_metadata <this-rollout-issue-link>` quick action to copy the labels from this rollout issue.
    - [ ] Link this rollout issue as a related issue.
    - [ ] Close this rollout issue.

**WARNING:** This approach has the downside that it makes it difficult for us to
[clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) the flag.
For example, on-premise users could disable the feature on their GitLab instance. But when you
remove the flag at some point, they suddenly see the feature as enabled and they can't roll it back
to the previous behavior. To avoid this potential breaking change, use this approach only for urgent
matters.

### Release the feature

After the feature has been [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release),
the [clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up)
should be done as soon as possible to permanently enable the feature and reduce complexity in the
codebase.

You can either [create a follow-up issue for Feature Flag Cleanup](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) or use the checklist below in this same issue.

<!-- The checklist here is to help stakeholders keep track of the feature flag status -->
- [x] Create a merge request to remove `<feature-flag-name>` feature flag. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [x] Remove all references to the feature flag from the codebase.
    - [x] Remove the YAML definitions for the feature from the repository.
    - [x] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [x] Ensure that the cleanup MR has been included in the release package.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the monthly release was tagged](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [x] `/chatops run release check <merge-request-url> <milestone>`
- [x] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [x] If not already done, clean up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel:
    - [x] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --dev --staging --staging-ref --production`
- [x] Close this rollout issue.

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> false
```

title: Changes tab breaks thread navigation in Overview tab
description: ## How to reproduce 1. Open an MR overview tab with at least 3 discussions 2. Click on any discussion's date 3. Go to Changes tab 4. Go back to Overview tab 5. Click on Go to previous unresolved thread button () many times until you reach the first discussion 6. Click more on that button Expectation: navigation should loop Reality: when first discussion is reached you will jump around 200 pixels up with each click on the navigation button ## Video demonstration ![Screen_Recording_2022-08-31_at_21.38.01](/uploads/3f74981ea9c13b9ab759782b1b793237/Screen_Recording_2022-08-31_at_21.38.01.mov)

title: Thread navigation in Changes tab causes unnecessary scrolling
description:
## How to reproduce

1. Open Changes tab for a large MR with discussions
2. Click on a date of any discussion (preferably deep down on the page)
3. Manually scroll the page from top to bottom

Expectation: page scrolls without any issues

Reality: when you get close to the last navigated discussion you'll be scrolled back to it

Update: since [discussion navigation is fixed by disabling Virtual scrolling](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/371557) the issue now occurs only if you click on a discussion.

## Video reproduction

![Screen_Recording_2022-08-31_at_21.29.36](/uploads/13220a5e315f6568c8eb9cb7a397d96d/Screen_Recording_2022-08-31_at_21.29.36.mov)

This is happening because the anchor in the URL is not removed when we're scrolled to a discussion. If we scroll far away from this discussion it will be removed from the DOM. When we return to it it's inserted back again and the scrolling logic triggers as if we're just opened the page.

title: Tasks are called "Issues" in Activity Feed when Closed by Merge Request
description:
### Summary

Tasks (new Work Items) are labeled as "Issues" in the Activity Feed after being closed by a Merge Request.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create an Issue (i.e. Issue `#1`)
2. Create Tasks on the Issue (Tasks `#2` and `#3`)
3. Create and merge an MR that closes one of the Tasks (i.e. "Closes `#3`")
4. Activity feed will show as "Closed issue `#3`"

### Example Project

See https://gitlab.com/Rwarcards762/testing-of-tasks

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Create Issue with Tasks:

![image](/uploads/c01eb12621a7be2284da9bcb501a7d94/image.png)

Showing ID of Task as proof:

![image](/uploads/762ed78853a4ab899937d2dd644f3d2e/image.png)

Open an MR that will close a Task upon Merge:

![image](/uploads/93d880fd3f8e91483a05fb652b8922c2/image.png)

MR even calls the task an Issue:

![image](/uploads/5b9f5efddd5cb2166eec4bde1362b277/image.png)

Once merged, the Task is closed, calling it an Issue:

![image](/uploads/1a2e4085fe790809c18e06458ee2f6b6/image.png)

Proof of it being closed:

![image](/uploads/93c34fbd3fd52c63603a473553d0062d/image.png)

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Item should be called a "Task."

#### GitLab Environment Info

Occurs on latest GitLab.com and on Self-hosted GitLab 15.3.x

title: [Feature flag] Rollout of `ci_cost_factors_narrow_os_contribution_by_plan`
description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Feature flag] Enable description of feature -->

## Summary

This issue is to rollout [the feature](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/352830) on production,
that is currently behind the `ci_cost_factors_narrow_os_contribution_by_plan` feature flag.

<!-- Short description of what the feature is about and link to relevant other issues. -->

## Owners

- Team: ~"group::pipeline execution" 
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_pipeline_execution`
- Best individual to reach out to: @allison.browne 
- PM: @jheimbuck_gl 

## Rollout Steps

### Rollout on non-production environments

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status ace509af6838bffd0642608e878cef87b9a0822f`
- [x] Enable the feature globally on non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set ci_cost_factors_narrow_os_contribution_by_plan true --dev --staging --staging-ref`
- [ ] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.
      The best environment to validate the feature in is [staging-canary](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/#staging-canary)
      as this is the first environment deployed to. Note you will need to make sure you are configured to use canary as outlined [here](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/canary-stage/)
      when accessing the staging environment in order to make sure you are testing appropriately.

### Specific rollout on production

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to both production and canary.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status ace509af6838bffd0642608e878cef87b9a0822f`
- If you're using [project-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab,gitlab-org/gitlab-foss,gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com ci_cost_factors_narrow_os_contribution_by_plan true`
- [ ] Verify that the feature works on the specific entries. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Preparation before global rollout

- [x] Ensure that you or a representative in development can be available for at least 2 hours after feature flag updates in production.
  If a different developer will be covering, or an exception is needed, please inform the oncall SRE by using the `@sre-oncall` Slack alias.
- [ ] Announce on [the feature issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/352830) an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com. 

### Global rollout on production

For visibility, all `/chatops` commands that target production should be executed in the `#production` slack channel and cross-posted (with the command results) to the responsible team's slack channel (`#g_TEAM_NAME`).

- [x] [Incrementally roll out](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#process) the feature.
  - If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform **actor-based** rollout.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set ci_cost_factors_narrow_os_contribution_by_plan 20 --actors`
    - [ ]     - [ ] `/chatops run feature set ci_cost_factors_narrow_os_contribution_by_plan 50 --actors`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set ci_cost_factors_narrow_os_contribution_by_plan true`
- [x] Announce on [the feature issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/352830) that the feature has been globally enabled.
- [x] Wait for [at least one day for the verification term](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release).

### Release the feature

After the feature has been [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release),
the [clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up)
should be done as soon as possible to permanently enable the feature and reduce complexity in the
codebase.

You can either [create a follow-up issue for Feature Flag Cleanup](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) or use the checklist below in this same issue.

<!-- The checklist here is to help stakeholders keep track of the feature flag status -->
- [x] Create a merge request to remove `ci_cost_factors_narrow_os_contribution_by_plan` feature flag. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [x] Remove all references to the feature flag from the codebase.
    - [x] Remove the YAML definitions for the feature from the repository.
    - [x] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [x] Ensure that the cleanup MR has been included in the release package.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the monthly release was tagged](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run release check <merge-request-url> <milestone>`
- [x] Close [the feature issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/352830) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status cd2ca2fa75c293eb8e1ca9aa0be542b6353760a0`
- [x] If not already done, clean up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel:
    - [x] `/chatops run feature delete ci_cost_factors_narrow_os_contribution_by_plan --dev --staging --staging-ref --production`
- [x] Close this rollout issue.

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set ci_cost_factors_narrow_os_contribution_by_plan false
```
